sen.j: 二階堂 貞藤（にかいどう さだふじ、文永4年（1267年） - 建武 (日本)元年12月28日 (旧暦)（1335年1月23日））は、鎌倉時代後期の御家人。
sen.e: Sadafuji NIKAIDO (1267-January 23, 1335) was the Gokenin (Vassal) at the end of Kamakura Period.

sen.j: 甲斐国山梨郡牧庄主で、嘉元3年（1305年）には鎌倉から夢窓疎石を招き浄居寺（山梨県山梨市、旧東山梨郡牧丘町）を再興。
sen.e: He headed Makisho, Yamanashi District, Kai Province, and reconstructed the Joko-ji Temple (located in Yamanashi City, Yamanashi Prefecture, former Makioka Town, Higashi Yamanashi District) by inviting Soseki MUSO.

sen.j: 正中 (日本)元年（1324年）、後醍醐天皇の倒幕計画が露見した正中の変において、『太平記』に拠れば鎌倉へ送られた後醍醐天皇誓書の判読を止めたという。
sen.e: According to the "Taiheiki" (The Record of the Great Peace), he supposedly stopped the deciphering of the imperial command of Emperor Godaigo sent to Kamakura during the Shochu no Hen (Shochu Disturbance) when the subjugation plan of Emperor Godaigo against the bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) was revealed in 1324.

sen.j: 元徳元年（1329年）、京都では後醍醐天皇と退位を求める持明院統の間で対立が発生し、双方が鎌倉へ働きかけており、3月には道蘊が使者として上洛。
sen.e: A conflict rose with the Jimyo-in Party which called for the resignation of Emperor Godaigo at Kyoto in 1329, and both parties were working toward Kamakura as Doun went to the capital (Kyoto) in March as a messenger.

A conflict rose with the Jimyo-in Party which called for the resignation of Emperor Godaigo at Kyoto in 1329, and both parties were working toward Kamakura as Doun went to the capital (Kyoto) in March as a messenger.

A conflict rose with Jimyoin-to (imperial lineage from Emperor Gofukakusa to Emperor Gokomatsu) which called for the resignation of Emperor Godaigo in Kyoto in 1329, and both were working toward Kamakura as Doun went to the capital (Kyoto) in April as a messenger.
sen.cmt: 元徳元年3月として、グレゴリオ暦に直しました。

sen.j: 道蘊は持明院統側に有利な独自の調停案を提示しており、北条貞顕は道蘊を批判し、『太平記』では「朝敵の第一」と道蘊評を記している。
sen.e: Doun presented the strong and original arbitration proposal, and Sadaaki HOJO criticized Doun and referred about him in "Taiheiki" as "the sole enemy of the imperial court."

Doun presented the strong and original arbitration proposal for Jimyoin-to side, and Sadaaki HOJO criticized Doun and referred about him in "Taiheiki" as 'the sole enemy of the imperial court.'

sen.j: 道蘊の独断に関しては、同年2月には政所執事の二階堂行貞が死去し、後任と目されていた道蘊の上洛中に行貞の子貞衡が補任されたことに対しての不満を示したものであるとする指摘もある（永井晋『金沢貞顕』）。
sen.e: The arbitrary decision was pointed as the indication of the disapproval of Doun concerning the assignment of Sadahira, who was the child of Yukisada NIKAIDO, who was the Mandokoro Shitsuji (chief of Mandokoro, the Administrative Board) and passed away in February of the same year, as the heir instead of Doun during his trip to Kyoto ("Sadaaki KANEZAWA" written by Susumu NAGAI).

The arbitrary decision was pointed as the indication of the disapproval of Doun concerning the assignment of Sadahira, who was the child of Yukisada NIKAIDO, who was the Mandokoro Shitsuji (chief of Mandokoro, the Administrative Board) and passed away in February of the same year, as the heir instead of Doun during his trip to Kyoto ("Sadaaki KANEZAWA" written by Susumu NAGAI).

Some points that the Doun's arbitrary decision indicated his disapproval of appointing Sadahira, the son of Yukisada NIKAIDO, as the successor of Sadayuki NIKAIDO, who was Mandokoro Shitsuji (chief of Mandokoro, the Administrative Board) and passed away in March of the same year, while Doun, Sadayuki's putative successor, was away in Kyoto ("KANEZAWA Sadaaki" written by Susumu NAGAI).
sen.cmt: 元徳元年2月としてグレゴリオ暦にし表現を変えました。

sen.j: 元徳2年（1330年）に引付頭人、甲斐国において再び夢窓を招き庄内に恵林寺（甲州市、旧塩山市）を創建。
sen.e: He became the head of Hikitsuke tonin (chairman of the court of justice) in 1330 and invited Muso to Kai Province again to establish the Erin-ji Temple (Koshu City, formerly Enzan City).

sen.e: He worked as the Mandokoro Shitsuji in 1332 and assisted Takatoki HOJO.

sen.e: He entered Kyoto with Takakage ADACHI as the messenger to demote the Emperor Godaigo in 1331, and also participated in the attack of Chihaya-jo Castle arranged by Masashige KUSUNOKI of Miya (imperial court) side.

sen.e: He participated in the Kenmu no Shinsei (Kenmu Restoration) after the fall of the Kamakura Bakufu and managed the jurisdiction over the Hokuriku Road as the Fourth Department of the Zasshoketsudansho (the part of the government that settled territorial disputes).
